options: Document that the patient has declined any further information and sign the consent form
Explain that to give no information may invalidate her consent
Explain to her what the treatment aims to achieve, what it will involve and any serious risks
Explain the procedure in brief but leave out any details which might worry her further
Respect her wishes and sign the consent form
questions:
You are a junior doctor in a surgical firm. You are keen to gain experience in this field and as such have assisted in a number of operations including appendicectomy. You are consenting a lady for an emergency laparoscopic appendicectomy. She seems very nervous and says she does not want to know the details of the operation, saying 'I'm in your safe hands Doc'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
In order to have effective discussions with patients about risk when obtaining consent for a procedure, you must identify the adverse outcomes that may result from the proposed options. This includes the potential outcome of taking no action. Risks will usually be side effects, complications, and failure of an intervention to achieve the desired aim. Risks can vary from common but minor side effects, to rare but serious adverse outcomes possibly resulting in permanent disability or death.

If a patient does not want to know in detail about the treatment, you should respect their wishes, as far as possible. But you must still give them the information they need in order to give their consent to the proposed treatment. This is likely to include what the treatment aims to achieve and what it will involve, for example: whether the procedure is invasive; what level of pain or discomfort they might experience, and what can be done to minimise it; anything they should do to prepare for the treatment; and if it involves any serious risks.

If a patient insists that they do not want even this basic information, you must explain the potential consequences of them not having it, particularly if it might mean that their consent is not valid (B). You must record the fact that the patient has declined this information. You must also make it clear that they can change their mind and have more information at any time.

Once you have warned them that you may not be able to obtain valid consent, you should go on to give the vital information in option C. Documentation is very important in tricky situations such as this, hence why (A) is the next best option. Option D is better than E as you have at least given the patient some information but none of the final 3 options will have realistically provided enough information to obtain valid consent.

title: Consent
body:
There are 3 types of consent:

1. Informed
2. Expressed
3. Implied

Consent forms used in UK NHS
Consent Form 1For competent adults who are able to consent for themselves where consciousness may be impaired (e.g. GA)
Consent Form 2For an adult consenting on behalf of a child where consciousness is impaired
Consent Form 3For an adult or child where consciousness is not impaired
Consent Form 4For adults who lack capacity to provide informed consent

Capacity
Key points include:
1. Understand and retain information
2. Patient believes the information to be true
3. Patient is able to weigh the information to make a decision
All patients must be assumed to have capacity

Consent in minors
Young children and older children who are not Gillick competent cannot consent for themselves. In British law the patient's biological mother can always provide consent. The childs father can consent if the parents are married (and the father is the biological father), or if the father is named on the birth certificate (irrespective of marital status). If parents are not married and the father is not named on the birth certificate then the father cannot consent.

options: Leave your other jobs and go and write the discharge summary
Ignore the nurse, she deserved it
Apologise to the nurse and explain that you have been busy and will deal with the matter as soon as you can
Hand the task over to the night team
Proceed to review the third ill patient and do the discharge summary later
questions:
On a busy shift on the ward, a nurse repeatedly asks you to write a discharge summary for a patient. You have three very unwell patients to see to and a list of bloods to sort. After reviewing two of the patients the nurse exclaims that she has told you many times already that this discharge summary needs doing. Out of frustration you throw some harsh words claiming you have many more important jobs to sort out first and you make the nurse cry.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The two immediate problems in hand are the sick patient who needs assessing and the nurse that you have now upset. It will take a couple of minutes to apologise and explain why you got so angry to the nurse. This shows courtesy and and addresses the problem in a timely manner. She is part of the nursing team and you will most likely need her help at some point in the future if not today and so it is best to address this issue immediately and try to rectify what you have done. As said, the nurse is there and clearly upset and apologising will very little time, this is ranked higher than E.

Option E is obviously the next most important task and so is ranked higher than the other options.

Although D is not ideal, it is important to get your more urgent jobs done as a priority. You are still taking responsibility by making arrangements to ensure the job gets completed and so is ranked higher than B and A.

Ignoring the nurse doesn't deal with the situation and the effectiveness of the team may be restricted if you just leave the nurse crying.

A is the worst option, it shows an inability to prioritise your jobs. If there is a seriously unwell patient on the ward, then they clearly need to be seen to first and takes precedence over a discharge summary.

options: Invite Dr Sharma to spend a day with your team to see the kind of patients that need admitting
Advise the patient to consider switching her GP
Suggest to the consultant that he goes back to the patient and apologises for the remarks
Speak to the consultant after the ward round and express your concern about his remarks with respect to Dr Sharma
Report the Consultant to management of making racially offensive remarks
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a surgical ward. During the morning ward round the team reviews a 28-year-old who has been admitted by her GP (Dr Sharma) for the third time with unexplained abdominal pain. The consultant expresses exasperation at the admission, commenting to the patient you need to go home and Dr Sharma needs to go back to medical school. He asks for her to be discharged if the ultrasound is normal and moves on to the next patient.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
From a clinical perspective recurrent admissions with unexplained abdominal pain, often in younger patients, are not uncommon and do not necessarily imply a failure of management. The vast majority of times such admissions are initiated by the patient. You may, or may not, be aware of this. The point is that as a ST1 doctor you are not in a good position to judge the actions of Dr Sharma.

Criticisms of colleagues may be legitimate but they should be made in private using the correct channels. Making disparaging remarks about another doctor in front of a patient is not only rude and unprofessional but it risks undermining the patient's confidence not only in that doctor (who she may have known, and trusted, for many years) but also the profession as a whole. You should therefore speak to consultant about your concerns, preferably at the end of the ward round rather than in the middle. If the consultant feels the patient is owed an apology he can go back and do this later.

The other three options are poor. Of course, spending time to educate colleagues about your area of specialism is useful but the answer implies that Dr Sharma is incompetent, something we have no evidence for. Advising her to switch GPs risks damaging an important long term relationship between doctor and patient, again without any real justification.

There is nothing to suggest that the consultant's comments were racist.

questions:
Whilst working on the colorectal ward an angry lady approaches you. She claims her mother has been made nil by mouth for two days now because her surgery keeps getting cancelled and she has just found out that her surgery is due to be cancelled for a third time. She says she will sue you and the hospital if no action is taken today.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Option D is the best option as this addresses the daughters concerns and informs them that you are taking their case seriously by taking the time to see what the problem with the surgery is.

C - Escalating the situation to a more senior doctor shows that some form of action is being taken. However, it would be best to speak to your senior about the situation first as this may be a problem you are able to rectify without their help.

E - Although not an ideal answer, it is ranked above A and B because the latter two are not directly dealing with the situation. This situation should be escalated first to your registrar before including the consultant.

A - It is important to document communication made with patients' relatives, especially if they are threatening legal action. However, this does not directly deal with the angry relative or patient immediately and so is ranked lower than the above.

B - This is highly inappropriate. You should always try to address a angry relative or patients problem in order to help rectify the problem.

options: Report the issue to your hospital's information governance department
Ask your fellow F2s what to do
Contact your medical defence union
Report the issue to your consultant
Do nothing as your personal USB stick is password protected
questions:
You are an F2 doctor carrying out an audit and have some patient data saved on a personal USB stick. When you get home, you find that the USB stick is no longer in your bag, and realise that you have lost it on your way home.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question covers the GMC guidelines on protecting information, which form part of the Confidentiality guidelines. The guidelines state that you must make sure that all patient information that you hold must always be effectively protected against improper disclosure.

The most appropriate source of advice in this situation is the hospital information governance department, who will be able to tell you how to proceed. The next best option is to ask your consultant. Asking your medical defence union is certainly an option, as they should be able to point you towards the information governance department, however asking local contacts is a better first choice. Asking your fellow F2s is less appropriate as they are likely to be no better placed than you to give advice about the situation. Not doing anything is not acceptable, as a personal USB stick, even if password protected, is unlikely to conform to NHS requirements for data storage.

GMC, Confidentiality, 2009, Paragraphs 12-16.

questions:
You are an FY2 doctor working in General Practice. A 12-year-old girl comes to see you accompanied by her mother. They tell you that the girl is currently in a sexual relationship with a 17-year-old. The mother says that the girl's partner is extremely caring and protective of her daughter but feels they should be using contraception.

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Sexual activity in someone under the age of 13 will always be a cause for concern. You should usually share information about sexual activity involving children under 13, who are considered in law to be unable to consent. While reporting to social services or the police should always be considered where the individual is very young, the obligation of health professionals is to act in the best interests of the patient and this requires flexibility.
You should discuss a decision not to disclose with a named or designated doctor for child protection and record your decision and the reasons for it. Where a health professional decides to disclose information to a third party against a child's wishes, the child should generally be told before disclosing the information.

title: Consent in children
body:
The law around consent in children is complicated. However, as a rough guide:
  • patients less than 16 years old may consent to treatment if they are deemed to be competent (an example is the Fraser guidelines, previously termed Gillick competence), but cannot refuse treatment which may be deemed in their best interest
  • between the ages of 16-18 years it is presumed patients are competent to give consent to treatment
  • patients 18 years or older may consent to treatment or refuse treatment

With regards to the provision of contraceptives to patients under 16 years of age the Fraser Guidelines state that all the following requirements should be fulfilled:
  • the young person understands the professional's advice
  • the young person cannot be persuaded to inform their parents
  • the young person is likely to begin, or to continue having, sexual intercourse with or without contraceptive treatment
  • unless the young person receives contraceptive treatment, their physical or mental health, or both, are likely to suffer
  • the young person's best interests require them to receive contraceptive advice or treatment with or without parental consent

questions:
You are taking routine bloods from two patients. Once you have sent the bloods you realise you put the wrong patient labels on the blood bottles.

Rank the following responses to the situation from most appropriate to least appropriate.
notes: In this situation it is important to be honest about your mistake by phoning the lab (A). Your registrar is a good source of advice when mistakes happen they will be able to get back to you quickly even if they are in clinic (E).  Reflection with your educational supervisor is a useful task however this will not help the situation (D). There is no need to phone your defence union for a minor mistake such as this however they will be a good source of advice (C). Attempting to right the problem yourself is dangerous as the wrong results will still be assigned to each patient electronically (B).

questions:
At the bus stop on the way home from work one day you overhear some medical students discussing a patient on the ward very loudly. They are not using patient identifiable information but are discussing his investigation results.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Telling them they are behaving inappropriately is the best option, as you are in a position of authority and should be responsible (2B.

Arranging a meeting would enable you to inform them they were wrong, but risks them disclosing patient information in the meantime (E).

Even though they use no patient information, the behaviour is inappropriate and they should be told so as soon as possible (A).

Calling hospital security is neither helpful nor appropriate, as it is not their job (C)

Using the opportunity to teach (D) would be hugely unprofessional, risks patient confidentiality, and would lead the students to believe that this behaviour is acceptable and normal.

options: The F2 doctor on the ward who has most contact with the patient
The doctor who performed the gastroscopy
His GP following discharge
The consultant in-charge of his care
His next-of-kin after you have told him/her
questions:
A 68-year-old man is admitted with haematemesis. A gastroscopy performed as an inpatient shows a carcinoma which is confirmed on biopsy. Who is the most appropriate person to inform the patient of the diagnosis?


Rank the following in order
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
One of the key aims of the entrance exam is to assess a doctors ability to act in a compassionate and empathetic way. Many of you may recall incidences of patients being told about a cancer diagnosis in inappropriate circumstances.

The most appropriate person to inform the patient in this scenario is the consultant. He/she is currently in charge of their care and will be best placed to answer questions about management and prognosis. The F2 doctor will be less able to do this but will at least be known to the patient.

The doctor who performed the gastroscopy is unlikely to know the patient apart from their brief meeting prior to the procedure. Asking the GP to tell the patient is a 'cop-out' on a number of levels. Firstly the patient may feel that the hospital team 'could not be bothered' to tell him themselves. Secondly it results in an unnecessary delay and thirdly the GP may not be best placed to give information on management and prognosis.

Telling the next-of-kin is the worst option as it breaks confidentiality.

options: Review the prescription sheet to check for errors
Discipline nurse for giving too much medication
Stop patient from taking medication
Speak to nurse who dispensed medication to see why the patient has more
Respect patient autonomous decision to take more medication
questions:
You are an F2 doctor on a Care of the Elderly ward. You see an elderly patient with dementia taking his morning medication. However, you notice that he has double the amount of a particular medication than you prescribed.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario places patient safety in jeopardy. The most important and first action that needs to be taken is to prevent the patient from taking the medication (C). Depending on the medication, taking too much could be dangerous, meaning preventing the patient from doing so is protecting patient safety. Once this is done, looking for the cause of the incident takes precedent.

Reviewing the prescription sheet to check for errors (A) will help to identify whether there is an error on the prescription sheet. If an error is present then this can be corrected at this point. Following this, speaking to the nurse who dispensed the medication (D) is the next most appropriate action. Speaking to the nurse may help you to realise where the error has occurred, or if there was an error on the prescription chart then inform the nurse that this was the case.

Discipling the nurse for giving too much medication (B) is an incorrect response. Firstly, it is unclear whether this incident has occurred due to a fault on the nurse's behalf, and secondly, it is not appropriate, or acceptable, for a nurse to be disciplined by a doctor.

Respecting the patient's autonomous decision to take more medication (E) is inappropriate. The patient has dementia and could likely have forgotten how many medications he takes, and the doses for each. This option places patient safety at risk.

Depending on the medication, taking too much could be dangerous, meaning preventing the patient from doing so is protecting patient safety. Once this is done, looking for the cause of the incident takes precedent.

Reviewing the prescription sheet to check for errors (A) will help to identify whether there is an error on the prescription sheet. If an error is present then this can be corrected at this point. Following this, speaking to the nurse who dispensed the medication (D) is the next most appropriate action. Speaking to the nurse may help you to realise where the error has occurred, or if there was an error on the prescription chart then inform the nurse that this was the case.

Discipling the nurse for giving too much medication (B) is an incorrect response. Firstly, it is unclear whether this incident has occurred due to a fault on the nurse's behalf, and secondly, it is not appropriate, or acceptable, for a nurse to be disciplined by a doctor.

Respecting the patient's autonomous decision to take more medication (E) is inappropriate. The patient has dementia and could likely have forgotten how many medications he takes, and the doses for each. This option places patient safety at risk.
